headline: Conor Lamb says John Fetterman skipping Muhlenberg College debate to avoid talking about 2013 gun incident with Black man
author: Marc Levy
sentences:
And we have to talk about it.”
Kenyatta, who is Black, said in an interview that Fetterman “needs to leave the candidate protection program and actually publicly debate his record.”
Fetterman has missed several forums, including one hosted by a predominantly Black church in Philadelphia.

HARRISBURG — Conor Lamb is accusing rival John Fetterman in Pennsylvania’s Democratic U.S. Senate primary of skipping candidate forums to avoid talking about a 2013 incident when, shotgun in hand, he confronted a Black man because he suspected the man was involved in gunfire nearby.

In a letter to The Philadelphia Inquirer last year, Miyares — writing from state prison, where he is serving time in an unrelated case — insisted that Fetterman knew he was Black and not only pointed the shotgun at him, but also loaded it.

“The people of Braddock understand that, as the town’s mayor and chief law enforcement officer, John was acting to keep his community safe,” Rebecca Katz, an adviser to Fetterman’s campaign, said in an email.

The man — Christopher Miyares, who is Black — was unarmed and said in a TV interview afterward that he had been jogging when Fetterman, who is white, pulled up in his pickup and pointed the shotgun at him.
Kenyatta, a state lawmaker, said the situation could have ended badly for Miyares as a Black man and that an apology from Fetterman would show people that he understands he may have made a mistake.
On Thursday night, Lamb, a third-term congressman, took to Twitter to raise the episode, which has bubbled just below the surface of a primary campaign that previously had been relatively cordial.
He has insisted he isn’t skipping forums for any such reason, and has repeatedly maintained that he was acting as a mayor concerned for public safety and confronted the man, not knowing his race.
A political action committee that supports Black candidates, including Kenyatta, raised it early last year and used it in advertisements on radio stations popular with Black listeners.
It might also damage Fetterman and his party with a key voting bloc whose support would be important should he become the Democratic candidate in the general election in November.
Fetterman, Pennsylvania’s lieutenant governor, announced Thursday that he would not attend Sunday’s debate at Muhlenberg College with Lamb and fellow Democrat, Malcolm Kenyatta.
He has said he pursued a mask- and goggle-wearing man he saw running nearby, covered head to toe in the cold January weather, pulling out a shotgun until police arrived.
“For years now, John has failed to apologize for his vigilante behavior and he doesn’t even own the fact that what he did was dangerous and wrong,” Kenyatta said.
The contest to replace retiring Republican Sen. Pat Toomey represents perhaps the Democrats’ best opportunity to pick up a seat in the closely divided Senate.
A Franklin & Marshall College poll in February found that Fetterman appeared to have an early lead in the Democratic primary, but many voters are undecided.
Braddock — a town that is about 70% Black — reelected Fetterman 10 months later “because they know this incident had nothing to do with race,” Katz said.
The accusation marks a sharp escalation in tone between candidates vying for the Democratic nomination in Pennsylvania’s May 17 Senate primary election.
His campaign pointed out Friday that it has agreed to join three televised debates in coming weeks and that Fetterman has joined numerous other forums.
Fetterman has spoken before of how he believed he had heard gunfire while outside his home in the small town of Braddock when he was mayor in 2013.
He has previously denied avoiding forums for anything other than legitimate scheduling conflicts or unforeseen family circumstances.
Fetterman’s campaign suggested that Lamb, who is white, is raising the encounter now because he isn’t breaking through with voters.
The accusation more directly inserts issues of race into a campaign that could hinge on which candidate appeals to Black voters.
“That’s a huge problem when we’re picking our nominee for the biggest race in the country,” Lamb wrote on Twitter.
“He doesn’t want to talk about the fact that he chased down an unarmed Black man and held him at gunpoint.
But until Thursday night, a Democratic rival had not used it in such a public way to go after Fetterman.
He also has suggested that Miyares was involved in something untoward that he was running away from.
Fetterman said he didn’t know Miyares’ race when he got into his pickup truck to pursue him.
“We all know why John Fetterman isn’t coming to the debate on Sunday,” Lamb wrote.
Fetterman has denied pointing the shotgun at Miyares and said it wasn’t loaded.
Republicans also have used it to attack Fetterman.
The subject has shadowed the campaign trail.
That’s the elephant in the room.
